details.title: Estimation of P[Y<X] for Weibull distributions
details.standardTitle: Estimation of P[Y<X] for Weibull distributions

p: Debasis Kundu is a Professor of Statistics in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur. He received his B-Stat in 1982, M.Stat in 1984 both from the Indian Statistical Institute, M.A (Mathematics) in 1985 from the University of Pittsburgh, and Ph.D. in 1989 from the Pennsylvania State University. He has worked in the University of Texas at Dallas from 1989 to 1990, and then joined Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur in 1990. His research interests include Statistical Signal Processing, Reliability Analysis, Statistical Computing, and Competing Risks Models.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. & Stat., Indian Inst. of Technol. Kanpur, India
authors.name: D. Kundu

p: Rameshwar D. Gupta was born in Bulandshahr, U.P., India, on March 3, 1948. He received the MSc degree from Meerut University in 1969; and the M.A., and Ph.D. degrees from Dalhousie University in 1970, and 1973, respectively.

In July 1980 he was appointed Associate Professor in the Department of Computer Science and Applied Statistics, the University of New Brunswick, Saint John Campus. He was promoted to the rank of Full Professor in July 1986. He has held administrative position of the Assistant Dean of Graduate studies for the period 1988–1990, and an acting Associate Dean of Graduate Studies for the period 2004–05. He is an author or co-author of more the 75 research papers. His research interests are statistical inference, multivariate statistical analysis, and statistical analysis of reliability and life-testing models.

details.abstract: This paper deals with the estimation of R=P[Y<X] when X, and Y are two independent Weibull distributions with different scale parameters, but having the same shape parameter. The maximum likelihood estimator, and the approximate maximum likelihood estimator of R are proposed. We obtain the asymptotic distribution of the maximum likelihood estimator of R. Based on the asymptotic distribution, the confidence interval of R can be obtained. We also propose two bootstrap confidence intervals. We consider the Bayesian estimate of R, and propose the corresponding credible interval for R. Monte Carlo simulations are performed to compare the different proposed methods. Analysis of a real data set has also been presented for illustrative purposes.

context.text: Following the approach of Berger & Sun [5], it is assumed that the prior density of \$\theta_{j}\$ is inverted \$IG(a_{j},b_{j})\$.

Two methods as suggested by Berger & Sun [5] can be adopted in this set up also: (a) specify the first two marginal moments for \$\theta_{j}\$; (b) specify the two marginal quantiles of \$\theta_{j}\$, and solve for (\$a_{j}\$, \$b_{j}\$).

context.text: Based on \$M\$, and \$R\$ values, using the method proposed by Chen & Shao [6], the approximate HPD credible interval of \$R\$ can be easily constructed.
We also compute the 95% highest posterior density (HPD) credible interval of \$R\$, based on the idea of Chen & Shao [6], and it is (0.7014, 0.8244).

links.abstract: We make an analogy between images and statistical mechanics systems. Pixel gray levels and the presence and orientation of edges are viewed as states of atoms or molecules in a lattice-like physical system. The assignment of an energy function in the physical system determines its Gibbs distribution. Because of the Gibbs distribution, Markov random field (MRF) equivalence, this assignment also determines an MRF image model. The energy function is a more convenient and natural mechanism for embod...

links.abstract: The minimum variance s-unbiased estimator of Pr{Y ⩽ X} is derived for the case in which X and Y are s-independent r.v.'s each with a Cdf belonging to the exponential family but otherwise not necessarily of the same type.

context.text: Kelley & Kelley & Schucany [20], Sathe & Shah [27], and Tong [30]–[32] considered the problem of estimating \$R\$ when \$X\$ & \$Y\$ are independent exponential random variables.

<tex>$P(Y<X)$</tex></ref_formula> for exponential families
